repnme.cdata!:
Jamaica - Emergency Economic Rehabilitation
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings show a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and modest institutional
            development impacts. Lessons learned address three main
            issues. First, a critical issue during preparation centered
            on the suitability of the instrument type to support the
            Government during its period of fiscal pressure: a
            multi-year investment loan was not adequate due to the need
            for a fast-disbursing mechanism, similarly was the case of
            an economic recovery loan, while the selected emergency
            recovery loan provided greater flexibility to ensure that
            social spending would not be reduced during the adjustment
            period. Second, while the loan delineated a number of policy
            reform actions sector wide - though appropriate - the
            breadth of the reform program did somehow detract the
            support to macroeconomic stability, and social efforts. It
            is thus suggested to consider in the future, a less
            comprehensive set of actions, particularly those not
            considered requirements for Board presentation, or
            effectiveness. Third, although the Government could have
            obtained additional resources from the International
            Monetary Fund (IMF), its entry at the time of the loan might
            have signaled investors with a much worse macroeconomic, and
            fiscal situation than anticipated; notwithstanding, the
            IMF's extension of its Staff Monitoring Program,
            favored more rigorous monitoring of the macroeconomic
            framework, providing an adequate coordination.

Jamaica - Emergency Economic Rehabilitation
            Loan Project

5087312.majtheme: Public sector governance,Human development,Social protection and risk management

repnme.cdata!:
Jamaica - Emergency Economic Rehabilitation
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Economic Rehabilitation
            Loan Project supports the Jamaican Government's efforts
            to maintain a sound macroeconomic program and continue its
            progress toward achievement of sustainable economic growth
            and further poverty reduction in the face of multiple shocks
            which have impacted the economy, especially the decline in
            international travel to and tourism in Jamaica following the
            events of September 11, 2001. It will bridge part of the
            fiscal gap generated by the shocks, help to maintain
            spending in key social programs, and rebuild damaged
            infrastructure; support private sector-led tourism and
            related economic activities; and improve overall governance
            in the country. The loan will help the Government avoid
            cutbacks in critical expenditures, especially in social
            programs. Improved public expenditure control,
            rationalization, and governance and transparency will
            increase administrative efficiency and improve the delivery
            of public services. Reforms and actions to improve the
            framework for private sector development, including a more
            flexible labor market, will stimulate growth and create
            employment opportunities for the poor, particularly in
            tourism and tourism-linked agriculture and manufacturing.
            The report also discusses three potential risks that the
            project would face.
